Overview.Name: Leigh syndrome
Overview.Synonyms: Infantile subacute necrotizing encephalopathy, Leigh disease, Leigh's disease, Leigh's necrotizing encephalopathy, LS, Necrotizing encephalopathy infantile subacute of Leigh, SNE, Subacute necrotizing encephalopathy
Overview.Description: A progressive neurological disease defined by specific neuropathological features associating brainstem and basal ganglia lesions.

Causes.Description:
Leigh syndrome can be caused by genetic changes in any of more than 75 different genes. Most of our genes are made up of DNA in the cell's nucleus (nuclear DNA). Some of our genes are made up of DNA in other cell structures called mitochondria (mitochondrial DNA, or mtDNA). Most people with Leigh syndrome have a genetic change in nuclear DNA, and about 20% have a genetic change in mtDNA.

Most genes associated with Leigh syndrome are involved in the process of energy production in mitochondria (oxidative phosphorylation). Five protein complexes, named complex I through complex IV, are involved in this process. Many of the genetic changes associated with Leigh syndrome disrupt the function of proteins in these complexes, how the complexes form, or additional steps related to energy production. Researchers believe that impaired oxidative phosphorylation may cause cells to die because they don't have enough energy. The death of brain cells likely contributes to the neurologic features of the condition, while the death of cells in other tissues may lead to additional symptoms in other parts of the body.

More information about the genes responsible for Leigh syndrome is available here on the Genetics Home Reference website.

Symptom.Name: Renal tubular dysfunction
Symptom.Synonyms: Abnormal function of filtrating structures in kidney; Renal tubular defect
Symptom.Description: Abnormal function of the renal tubule. The basic functional unit of the kidney, the nephron, consists of a renal corpuscle attached to a renal tubule, with roughly 0.8 to 1.5 nephrons per adult kidney. The functions of the renal tubule include reabsorption of water, electrolytes, glucose, and amino acids and secretion of substances such as uric acid.

Symptom.Name: Optic atrophy
Symptom.Synonyms: Optic nerve atrophy; Optic-nerve degeneration
Symptom.Description: Atrophy of the optic nerve. Optic atrophy results from the death of the retinal ganglion cell axons that comprise the optic nerve and manifesting as a pale optic nerve on fundoscopy.

Symptom.Name: Spasticity
Symptom.Synonyms: Involuntary muscle stiffness, contraction, or spasm; Muscle spasticity; Muscular spasticity
Symptom.Description: A motor disorder characterized by a velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch reflexes with increased muscle tone, exaggerated (hyperexcitable) tendon reflexes.

Symptom.Name: Spastic diplegia
Symptom.Synonyms: Spastic diparesis; Spastic diplegic
Symptom.Description: Spasticity (neuromuscular hypertonia) primarily in the muscles of the legs, hips, and pelvis.

Symptom.Name: Cerebellar atrophy
Symptom.Synonyms: Atrophic cerebellum; Degeneration of cerebellum
Symptom.Description: Cerebellar atrophy is defined as a cerebellum with initially normal structures, in a posterior fossa with normal size, which displays enlarged fissures (interfolial spaces) in comparison to the foliae secondary to loss of tissue. Cerebellar atrophy implies irreversible loss of tissue and result from an ongoing progressive disease until a final stage is reached or a single injury, e.g. an intoxication or infectious event.

Symptom.Name: Dystonia
Symptom.Synonyms: Dystonic movements
Symptom.Description: An abnormally increased muscular tone that causes fixed abnormal postures. There is a slow, intermittent twisting motion that leads to exaggerated turning and posture of the extremities and trunk.

Symptom.Name: Failure to thrive
Symptom.Synonyms: Faltering weight; Postnatal failure to thrive; Weight faltering
Symptom.Description: Failure to thrive (FTT) refers to a child whose physical growth is substantially below the norm.

Symptom.Name: Intrauterine growth retardation
Symptom.Synonyms: In utero growth retardation; Intrauterine growth failure; Intrauterine growth restriction; Intrauterine growth retardation, IUGR; Intrauterine retardation; IUGR; Prenatal growth deficiency; Prenatal growth failure; Prenatal growth retardation; Prenatal onset growth retardation; Prenatal-onset growth retardation; Small for gestational age infant
Symptom.Description: An abnormal restriction of fetal growth with fetal weight below the tenth percentile for gestational age.

Symptom.Name: Ventricular septal defect
Symptom.Synonyms: Hole in heart wall separating two lower heart chambers; Ventricular septal defects; Ventriculoseptal defect; VSD
Symptom.Description: A hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart. The defect is centered around the most superior aspect of the ventricular septum.

Symptom.Name: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
Symptom.Synonyms: Cardiomyopathy, hypertrophic; Enlarged and thickened heart muscle; HCM
Symptom.Description: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is defined by the presence of increased ventricular wall thickness or mass in the absence of loading conditions (hypertension, valve disease) sufficient to cause the observed abnormality.

Symptom.Name: Abnormality of extrapyramidal motor function
Symptom.Synonyms: Extrapyramidal dysfunction; Extrapyramidal signs; Extrapyramidal symptoms; Extrapyramidal syndrome; Extrapyramidal tract signs
Symptom.Description: A neurological condition related to lesions of the basal ganglia leading to typical abnormalities including akinesia (inability to initiate changes in activity and perform volitional movements rapidly and easily), muscular rigidity (continuous contraction of muscles with constant resistance to passive movement), chorea (widespread arrhythmic movements of a forcible, rapid, jerky, and restless nature), athetosis (inability to sustain the muscles of the fingers, toes, or other group of muscles in a fixed position), and akathisia (inability to remain motionless).

Symptom.Name: Hypoplasia of the corpus callosum
Symptom.Synonyms: Corpus callosum hypoplasia; Hypoplasia of corpus callosum; Hypoplastic corpus callosum; Underdevelopment of part of brain called corpus callosum
Symptom.Description: Underdevelopment of the corpus callosum.

Symptom.Name: Gliosis
Symptom.Synonyms: Cerebral gliosis; Excess astrocytes in brain
Symptom.Description: Gliosis is the focal proliferation of glial cells in the central nervous system.

Symptom.Name: Leukodystrophy
Symptom.Synonyms: Degeneration of white matter of brain
Symptom.Description: Leukodystrophy refers to deterioration of white matter of the brain resulting from degeneration of myelin sheaths in the CNS. Their basic defect is directly related to the synthesis and maintenance of myelin membranes. Symmetric white matter involvement at MRI is a typical finding in patients with leukodystrophies.

Symptom.Name: Sensory axonal neuropathy
Symptom.Synonyms: Axonal sensory neuropathy
Symptom.Description: An axonal neuropathy of peripheral sensory nerves.

Symptom.Name: Involuntary movements
Symptom.Synonyms: Involuntary movements; Involuntary muscle contractions
Symptom.Description: Involuntary contractions of muscle leading to involuntary movements of extremities, neck, trunk, or face.

Symptom.Name: Diffuse spongiform leukoencephalopathy
Symptom.Synonyms: Not specified
Symptom.Description: Not specified

Symptom.Name: Severe viral infection
Symptom.Synonyms: Not specified
Symptom.Description: An unusually severe viral infection.

Symptom.Name: Abnormality of movement
Symptom.Synonyms: Abnormality of movement; Movement disorder; Unusual movement
Symptom.Description: An abnormality of movement with a neurological basis characterized by changes in coordination and speed of voluntary movements.

Symptom.Name: Neuronal loss in basal ganglia
Symptom.Synonyms: Not specified
Symptom.Description: A reduction in the number of nerve cells in the basal ganglia.

Symptom.Name: Macrotia
Symptom.Synonyms: Large ears; Large pinnae
Symptom.Description: Median longitudinal ear length greater than two standard deviations above the mean and median ear width greater than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or, apparent increase in length and width of the pinna (subjective).

Symptom.Name: Ophthalmoplegia
Symptom.Synonyms: Eye muscle paralysis; Paralysis of extraocular eye movement
Symptom.Description: Paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles that are responsible for eye movements.

Symptom.Name: Nystagmus
Symptom.Synonyms: Involuntary, rapid, rhythmic eye movements
Symptom.Description: Rhythmic, involuntary oscillations of one or both eyes related to abnormality in fixation, conjugate gaze, or vestibular mechanisms.

Symptom.Name: Eczema
Symptom.Synonyms: Eczema
Symptom.Description: Eczema is a form of dermatitis. The term eczema is broadly applied to a range of persistent skin conditions and can be related to a number of underlying conditions. Manifestations of eczema can include dryness and recurring skin rashes with redness, skin edema, itching and dryness, crusting, flaking, blistering, cracking, oozing, or bleeding.

Symptom.Name: Agenesis of corpus callosum
Symptom.Synonyms: Absence of corpus callosum; Absent corpus callosum; Agenesis of the corpus callosum; Callosal agenesis; Corpus callosum agenesis; Dysplastic or absent corpus callosum
Symptom.Description: Absence of the corpus callosum as a result of the failure of the corpus callosum to develop, which can be the result of a failure in any one of the multiple steps of callosal development including cellular proliferation and migration, axonal growth or glial patterning at the midline.

Symptom.Name: Growth delay
Symptom.Synonyms: Delayed growth; Growth deficiency; Growth delay; Growth failure; Growth retardation; Poor growth; Retarded growth
Symptom.Description: A deficiency or slowing down of growth pre- and postnatally.

Symptom.Name: Congestive heart failure
Symptom.Synonyms: Cardiac failure; Cardiac failures; Cardiac insufficiency; CHF; Chronic heart failure; Heart failure
Symptom.Description: The presence of an abnormality of cardiac function that is responsible for the failure of the heart to pump blood at a rate that is commensurate with the needs of the tissues or a state in which abnormally elevated filling pressures are required for the heart to do so. Heart failure is frequently related to a defect in myocardial contraction.

Symptom.Name: Anemia
Symptom.Synonyms: Anaemia; Low number of red blood cells or hemoglobin
Symptom.Description: A reduction in erythrocytes volume or hemoglobin concentration.

Symptom.Name: Abnormal facial shape
Symptom.Synonyms: Abnormal facial shape; Abnormal morphology of the face; Distinctive facies; Dysmorphic facial features; Dysmorphic facies; Facial dysmorphism; Unusual facial appearance; Unusual facies
Symptom.Description: An abnormal morphology (form) of the face or its components.

Symptom.Name: Dysphagia
Symptom.Synonyms: Difficulty swallowing; Poor swallowing; Swallowing difficulties; Swallowing difficulty
Symptom.Description: Difficulty in swallowing.

Symptom.Name: Chorea
Symptom.Synonyms: Choreic movements; Choreiform movements
Symptom.Description: Chorea (Greek for 'dance') refers to widespread arrhythmic involuntary movements of a forcible, jerky and restless fashion. It is a random-appearing sequence of one or more discrete involuntary movements or movement fragments. Movements appear random because of variability in timing, duration or location. Each movement may have a distinct start and end. However, movements may be strung together and thus may appear to flow randomly from one muscle group to another. Chorea can involve the trunk, neck, face, tongue, and extremities.

Symptom.Name: Status epilepticus
Symptom.Synonyms: Prolonged seizure; Repeated seizure without recovery; Repeated seizures without recovery between them
Symptom.Description: Status epilepticus is a type of prolonged seizure resulting either from the failure of the mechanisms responsible for seizure termination or from the initiation of mechanisms which lead to abnormally prolonged seizures (after time point t1). It is a condition that can have long-term consequences (after time point t2), including neuronal death, neuronal injury, and alteration of neuronal networks, depending on the type and duration of seizures.

Symptom.Name: Distal muscle weakness
Symptom.Synonyms: Distal limb muscle weakness; Distal limb weakness; Distal muscular weakness; Distal paresis; Muscle weakness, distal; Muscle weakness, distal limbs, due to neuronopathy; Weakness of distal muscles; Weakness of outermost muscles
Symptom.Description: Reduced strength of the musculature of the distal extremities.

Symptom.Name: Increased CSF lactate
Symptom.Synonyms: Hyperlactatorachia; Increased cerebrospinal fluid lactate; Increased CSF lactic acid
Symptom.Description: Increased concentration of lactate in the cerebrospinal fluid.

Symptom.Name: Psychomotor retardation
Symptom.Synonyms: Motormental retardation; Psychomotor impairment; Psychomotor slowing
Symptom.Description: Not specified

Symptom.Name: Encephalomalacia
Symptom.Synonyms: Cerebral softening
Symptom.Description: Encephalomalacia is the softening or loss of brain tissue after cerebral infarction, cerebral ischemia, infection, craniocerebral trauma, or other injury.

Symptom.Name: Nephrotic syndrome
Symptom.Synonyms: Nephrosis
Symptom.Description: Nephrotic syndrome is a collection of findings resulting from glomerular dysfunction with an increase in glomerular capillary wall permeability associated with pronounced proteinuria. Nephrotic syndrome refers to the constellation of clinical findings that result from severe renal loss of protein, with Proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia.

Symptom.Name: Ptosis
Symptom.Synonyms: Blepharoptosis; Drooping upper eyelid; Eyelid ptosis
Symptom.Description: The upper eyelid margin is positioned 3 mm or more lower than usual and covers the superior portion of the iris (objective); or, the upper lid margin obscures at least part of the pupil (subjective).

Symptom.Name: Abnormality of the skeletal system
Symptom.Synonyms: Abnormality of the skeletal system; Skeletal abnormalities; Skeletal anomalies
Symptom.Description: An abnormality of the skeletal system.

Symptom.Name: Ataxia
Symptom.Synonyms: Cerebellar ataxia
Symptom.Description: Cerebellar ataxia refers to ataxia due to dysfunction of the cerebellum. This causes a variety of elementary neurological deficits including asynergy (lack of coordination between muscles, limbs and joints), dysmetria (lack of ability to judge distances that can lead to under- or overshoot in grasping movements), and dysdiadochokinesia (inability to perform rapid movements requiring antagonizing muscle groups to be switched on and off repeatedly).

Symptom.Name: Choreoathetosis
Symptom.Synonyms: Choreoathetoid movements
Symptom.Description: Involuntary movements characterized by both athetosis (inability to sustain muscles in a fixed position) and chorea (widespread jerky arrhythmic movements).

Symptom.Name: Hepatic failure
Symptom.Synonyms: Liver failure
Symptom.Description: Not specified

Symptom.Name: Neutropenia
Symptom.Synonyms: Low blood neutrophil count; Low neutrophil count; Peripheral neutropenia
Symptom.Description: An abnormally low number of neutrophils in the peripheral blood.
Symptom.Body System Category(-ies): immune system; blood and blood-forming tissues

Symptom.Name: Progressive neurologic deterioration
Symptom.Synonyms: Neurologic deterioration; Neurologic deterioration, progressive; Progressive mental deterioration; Progressive neurodegeneration; Worsening neurological symptoms
Symptom.Description: Not specified

Symptom.Name: Hyperkinetic movements
Symptom.Synonyms: Hyperkinesia; Hyperkinesis; Muscle spasms
Symptom.Description: Motor hyperactivity with excessive movement of muscles of the body as a whole.

Symptom.Name: Olivopontocerebellar atrophy
Symptom.Synonyms: Olivopontocerebellar degeneration
Symptom.Description: Neuronal degeneration in the cerebellum, pontine nuclei, and inferior olivary nucleus.

Symptom.Name: Respiratory failure
Symptom.Synonyms: Respiratory failure
Symptom.Description: A severe form of respiratory insufficiency characterized by inadequate gas exchange such that the levels of oxygen or carbon dioxide cannot be maintained within normal limits.

Symptom.Name: Myopathy
Symptom.Synonyms: Muscle tissue disease; Myopathic changes
Symptom.Description: A disorder of muscle unrelated to impairment of innervation or neuromuscular junction.

Symptom.Name: Peripheral neuropathy
Symptom.Synonyms: Peripheral nerve damage; Peripheral neuritis
Symptom.Description: Peripheral neuropathy is a general term for any disorder of the peripheral nervous system. The main clinical features used to classify peripheral neuropathy are distribution, type (mainly demyelinating versus mainly axonal), duration, and course.

Symptom.Name: Frontal hirsutism
Symptom.Synonyms: Hairy forehead; Hirsute forehead
Symptom.Description: Excessive amount of hair growth on forehead.

Symptom.Name: Feeding difficulties
Symptom.Synonyms: Feeding difficulties; Feeding problems; Poor feeding
Symptom.Description: Impaired ability to eat related to problems gathering food and getting ready to suck, chew, or swallow it.

Symptom.Name: Infantile spasms
Symptom.Synonyms: Not specified
Symptom.Description: Infantile spasms represent a subset of \"epileptic spasms\". Infantile Spasms are epileptic spasms starting in the first year of life (infancy).

Symptom.Name: Abnormal dentate nucleus morphology
Symptom.Synonyms: Abnormality of the dentate nucleus
Symptom.Description: An abnormality of the dentate nucleus.

Symptom.Name: High forehead
Symptom.Synonyms: High forehead
Symptom.Description: An abnormally increased height of the forehead.

Symptom.Name: Sensorineural hearing impairment
Symptom.Synonyms: Hearing loss, sensorineural; Sensorineural deafness; Sensorineural hearing loss
Symptom.Description: A type of hearing impairment in one or both ears related to an abnormal functionality of the cochlear nerve.

Symptom.Name: Cataract
Symptom.Synonyms: Cataracts; Clouding of the lens of the eye; Cloudy lens; Lens opacities; Lens opacity
Symptom.Description: A cataract is an opacity or clouding that develops in the crystalline lens of the eye or in its capsule.

Symptom.Name: Abnormality of the optic nerve
Symptom.Synonyms: optic nerve abnormalities; Optic nerve issue
Symptom.Description: Abnormality of the optic nerve.

Symptom.Name: Hypertrichosis
Symptom.Synonyms: Not specified
Symptom.Description: Hypertrichosis is increased hair growth that is abnormal in quantity or location.

Symptom.Name: Seizure
Symptom.Synonyms: Epileptic seizure; Seizures
Symptom.Description: A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain.

Symptom.Name: Muscle weakness
Symptom.Synonyms: Muscle weakness; Muscular weakness
Symptom.Description: Reduced strength of muscles.

Symptom.Name: Alopecia
Symptom.Synonyms: Hair loss
Symptom.Description: A noncongenital process of hair loss, which may progress to partial or complete baldness.

Symptom.Name: Athetosis
Symptom.Synonyms: Athetoid movements; Involuntary writhing movements; Involuntary writhing movements in fingers, hands, toes, and feet
Symptom.Description: A slow, continuous, involuntary writhing movement that prevents maintenance of a stable posture. Athetosis involves continuous smooth movements that appear random and are not composed of recognizable sub-movements or movement fragments. In contrast to chorea, in athetosis, the same regions of the body are repeatedly involved. Athetosis may worsen with attempts at movement of posture, but athetosis can also occur at rest.

Symptom.Name: Developmental regression
Symptom.Synonyms: Loss of developmental milestones; Mental deterioration in childhood; Neurodevelopmental regression; Psychomotor regression; Psychomotor regression beginning in infancy; Psychomotor regression in infants; Psychomotor regression, progressive
Symptom.Description: Loss of developmental skills, as manifested by loss of developmental milestones.

Symptom.Name: Upper motor neuron dysfunction
Symptom.Synonyms: Corticospinal tract dysfunction; Pyramidal tract dysfunction
Symptom.Description: A functional anomaly of the upper motor neuron. The upper motor neurons are neurons of the primary motor cortex which project to the brainstem and spinal chord via the corticonuclear, corticobulbar and corticospinal (pyramidal) tracts. They are involved in control of voluntary movements. Dysfunction leads to weakness, impairment of fine motor movements, spasticity, hyperreflexia and abnormal pyramidal signs.

Symptom.Name: Gastrointestinal dysmotility
Symptom.Synonyms: GI dysmotility
Symptom.Description: Abnormal intestinal contractions, such as spasms and intestinal paralysis, related to the loss of the ability of the gut to coordinate muscular activity because of endogenous or exogenous causes.

Symptom.Name: Abnormal pattern of respiration
Symptom.Synonyms: Abnormal pattern of respiration; Abnormal respiratory patterns; Unusual breathing patterns
Symptom.Description: An anomaly of the rhythm or depth of breathing.

Symptom.Name: Multiple joint contractures
Symptom.Synonyms: Not specified
Symptom.Description: Not specified

Symptom.Name: Skeletal muscle atrophy
Symptom.Synonyms: Amyotrophy; Amyotrophy involving the extremities; Muscle atrophy; Muscle atrophy, neurogenic; Muscle degeneration; Muscle hypotrophy; Muscle wasting; Muscular atrophy; Neurogenic muscle atrophy; Neurogenic muscle atrophy, especially in the lower limbs; Neurogenic muscular atrophy
Symptom.Description: The presence of skeletal muscular atrophy (which is also known as amyotrophy).

Symptom.Name: Infantile muscular hypotonia
Symptom.Synonyms: Decreased muscle tone in infant; Hypotonia early; Hypotonia in infancy; Hypotonia, early; Infantile hypotonia
Symptom.Description: Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in infancy.

Symptom.Name: Dyskinesia
Symptom.Synonyms: Disorder of involuntary muscle movements; Dyskinesis
Symptom.Description: A movement disorder which consists of effects including diminished voluntary movements and the presence of involuntary movements.

Symptom.Name: Brain imaging abnormality
Symptom.Synonyms: Abnormal brain imaging
Symptom.Description: An anomaly of metabolism or structure of the brain identified by imaging.

Lab.Name: Renal tubular acidosis
Lab.Synonyms: Accumulation of acid in body due to kidney problem
Lab.Description: Acidosis owing to malfunction of the kidney tubules with accumulation of metabolic acids and hyperchloremia, potentially leading to complications including hypokalemia, hypercalcinuria, nephrolithiasis and nephrocalcinosis.

Lab.Name: Lactic acidosis
Lab.Synonyms: Hyperlacticacidemia; Increased lactate in body; Lactic acidemia; Lacticacidemia; Lacticacidosis
Lab.Description: An abnormal buildup of lactic acid in the body, leading to acidification of the blood and other bodily fluids.

Lab.Name: 3-Methylglutaconic aciduria
Lab.Description: An increased amount of 3-methylglutaconic acid in the urine.

Lab.Name: Decreased activity of mitochondrial complex II
Lab.Description: A reduction in the activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex II, which is part of the electron transport chain in mitochondria.

Lab.Name: Complex organic aciduria
Lab.Description: Not specified

Lab.Name: Decreased activity of mitochondrial complex I
Lab.Description: A reduction in the activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex I, which is part of the electron transport chain in mitochondria.

Lab.Name: Decreased biotinidase level
Lab.Description: A decrease in the biotinidase level, an enzyme that releases biotin from biocytin, the product of biotin-dependent carboxylases degradation.

Lab.Name: Ketoacidosis
Lab.Description: Acidosis resulting from accumulation of ketone bodies.

Lab.Name: Hyperalaninemia
Lab.Synonyms: Increased blood alanine; Increased serum alanine
Lab.Description: An increased concentration of alanine in the blood.

Lab.Name: Lacticaciduria
Lab.Synonyms: High urine lactic acid levels; Increased urine lactate
Lab.Description: An increased concentration of lactic acid in the urine.

Lab.Name: Hypoglycemia
Lab.Description: A decreased concentration of glucose in the blood.

Lab.Name: Decreased activity of mitochondrial respiratory chain
Lab.Description: Decreased activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain.

Lab.Name: Abnormal enzyme/coenzyme activity
Lab.Description: An altered ability of any enzyme or their cofactors to act as catalysts. This term includes changes due to altered levels of an enzyme.

Lab.Name: Increased serum lactate
Lab.Description: Abnormally increased level of blood lactate (2-hydroxypropanoic acid). Lactate is produced from pyruvate by lactate dehydrogenase during normal metabolism. The terms lactate and lactic acid are often used interchangeably but lactate (the component measured in blood) is strictly a weak base whereas lactic acid is the corresponding acid. Lactic acidosis is often used clinically to describe elevated lactate but should be reserved for cases where there is a corresponding acidosis (pH below 7.35).

Lab.Name: Generalized aminoaciduria
Lab.Description: An increased concentration of all types of amino acid in the urine.

Lab.Name: Decreased activity of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex
Lab.Synonyms: Decreased activity of the PDH complex; Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency
Lab.Description: Not specified

Lab.Name: Ethylmalonic aciduria
Lab.Description: An increased concentration of ethylmalonic acid in the urine.

Lab.Name: Decreased activity of mitochondrial complex IV
Lab.Description: A reduction in the activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex IV, which is part of the electron transport chain in mitochondria.

Lab.Name: Decreased activity of mitochondrial complex III
Lab.Description: A reduction in the activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex III, which is part of the electron transport chain in mitochondria.

Lab.Name: Methylmalonic aciduria
Lab.Synonyms: High blood methylmalonic acid levels; Methymalonicaciduria
Lab.Description: Increased concentration of methylmalonic acid in the urine.

Support Organizations.Name: Alianza Iberoamericana de Enfermedades Raras o Poco Frecuentes

_comments.Deprecated Fields: Fields not displayed on the website have been preserved for reference.
_comments.Source Fields: All source fields were extracted from the original JSON.
